title: Ageing, Health and Society
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of population ageing from the bio-physiological and sociological perspectives. It focuses on the development of a multi-dimensional understanding of the factors that affect the health of older adults and the ways that socio-demographic changes shape societal attitudes towards old age. Emphasis is placed on discussions of the impact of population ageing on the social and health care needs of a society.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Analyze the global trends of population ageing and their impact on health care, social and economic issues in society. 2. Develop theoretical understandings in the societal changes in ageing. 3. Justify the social construction of "age" and "ageing process" in individual and social contexts. 4. Synthesize the impact of population ageing on health and social care needs in society.
syllabus: 1. Global trends of population ageing. 2. Ageing theories. 3. Gender issues in old age. 4. Health patterning among older adults. 5. Changing roles and relationships over life course. 6. Social construction of being old. 7. Ageing and medicalization. 8. Ethical and social dilemma in care for older adults. 9. Ageing and health policy. 10. Impact of population ageing on health and social care in society.

description: The aim of this course is to equip students with foundational knowledge and essential skills to address the basic care needs of older people. Emphasis is placed on promoting an understanding of the basic principles of care to help older people to meet their basic life needs. Fundamental concepts such as nutrition, exercise, oral care, basic hygiene care, foot and nail care, communication, and psychosocial care are also covered.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Explain the purposes and content of various geriatric assessment tools. 2. Demonstrate the ability to conduct comprehensive assessment to determine the biopsychosocial needs and conditions of the older people and their families. 3. Formulate individualized care plan and deliver client education for the older people and their families. 4. Describe the principles and demonstrate the ability to perform basic skills for providing care to older people safely and effectively. 5. Discuss the special issues relating to the provision of basic care to older people. The issues include infection control, occupational safety, promotion of independence, advanced and assisted technologies, and interprofessional practice. 6. Develop an awareness of providing current, innovative and evidence-based care through the application of relevant research findings, and lead innovation in aged care.
syllabus: 1. Methods of conducting a comprehensive assessment to identify basic care needs of older people. The content includes vital signs monitoring, blood glucose monitoring, skin inspection, assessment of activities of daily living (ADL) and cognitive and mood assessment, that reflect the body's physiologic status. 2. Risk assessment for common physical and psychosocial problems in older people, such as constipation, fall, depression and social isolation, and the associated preventive measures. 3. Principles and skills commonly adopted in care delivery to address the basic needs of older people, including skin care, oral care, basic hygiene care, foot and nail care, sleep hygiene, nutrition and mobility. 4. Knowledge and skills in supporting healthcare professionals to deliver complex geriatric medical and nursing care. 5. Special issues relating to the provision of basic care to older people. These issues include infection control, occupational safety, promotion of independence, first aid, advanced and assisted technologies.

title: Promoting Successful Ageing: Individual and Societal Perspectives
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the concepts, principles and theories of successful ageing from the health and social perspectives. Emphasis is placed on exploring and discussing the subjective and objective dimensions of successful ageing, the modifiable factors affecting the achievement of successful ageing, and the strategies to promote successful ageing at both individual and societal levels.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Describe the different terminologies and definitions of successful ageing. 2. Describe the concepts and principles of successful ageing from a theoretical perspective and a lay perspective. 3. Discuss the attributes representing successful ageing from both subjective and objective dimensions. 4. Discuss how successful ageing is related to the adaptation of physical, psychosocial and cognitive changes in later life. 5. Discuss how successful ageing is related to social change and the social environment. 6. Discuss the strategies to promote successful ageing at individual, family and societal levels. 7. Discuss the concepts and strategies to build an age-friendly community.
syllabus: 1. Concepts and principles of successful ageing 2. Biographical approaches to care in relation to successful ageing 3. Factors affecting successful ageing 4. Adapting to successful ageing 5. Promoting successful ageing 6. Concepts of age-friendly community

description: This course comprises both theoretical and practical components to enhance students’ understanding of the complexities of caring for older people with major chronic diseases. It takes an interdisciplinary approach to chronic disease management from the health and social perspectives. Emphasis is placed on the care designed to directly address the physical and psychosocial consequences of chronic disease for older people and their caregivers.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Discuss the physical and psychosocial impacts of chronic diseases on older people.  2. Identify the roles of different healthcare disciplines in managing major chronic diseases in older people.  3. Identify the issues relating to pharmaceutical care in older people.  4. Understand the concepts of multiple morbidity and comorbidity and their implications for long-term care.  5. Discuss the self-care models for chronic disease management and strategies to empower older people managing their diseases.  6. Discuss the types and roles of community resources in supporting older people living with chronic conditions.  7. Define quality of life and justify the interventions for promoting positive adjustment in older people with chronic diseases.  8. Apply related principles and utilise research findings in the care of older people with chronic diseases.  9. Discuss the role of complementary and alternative medicine in chronic disease management.  10. Demonstrate the ability to offer psychosocial support and interventions in caring for older people experiencing chronic diseases and their families.
syllabus: 1. Major chronic diseases among older people: prevalence, etiology and clinical manifestations.  2. The impacts of major chronic diseases on physical and psychosocial health of older people.  3. The roles of different healthcare disciplines in chronic disease management.  4. Special considerations for supporting pharmaceutical care in older people.  5. The changing patterns of disease and illness.  6. Biographical disruption regarding on chronic illness.  7. Help-seeking and responses to treatment.  8. The concepts of multiple morbidity and comorbidity and their implications for long-term care.  9. Conceptual models to explain self-care and patient empowerment strategies.  10. Introduction to innovative models of chronic disease management.  11. The role and trend towards integrating complementary and alternative medicine in chronic disease management.  12. The concept of quality of life and interventions for promoting positive adjustment in older people with chronic diseases.

title: Dementia: Prevention and Management
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the pathophysiological, behavioural and psychosocial aspects of dementia. Emphasis is placed on equipping students with the knowledge and skills required to prevent, detect and manage dementia in older people. The course also highlights the roles of family caregivers, multidisciplinary care team, and community care services in managing dementia.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Describe the etiologies, pathophysiologies, risk factors, types, and stages of dementia.  2. Describe the comprehensive health and social assessment for dementia.  3. Discuss the physical, cognitive, behavioural and psychosocial manifestations of dementia and the patients' care needs.  4. Describe the pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions for dementia.  5. Discuss the evidence-based care in managing dementia in community, rehabilitative and long-term care settings.  6. Describe the role of assistive technology in dementia care and drive innovation in practice.  7. Discuss the interventions to maintain and promote brain health.  8. Discuss the role of interprofessional team approach in the care of older people with dementia and their caregivers and families.  9. Discuss the role of informal caregivers in the care of older people with dementia.  10. Discuss the role of health and social care services in the care of older people with dementia.
syllabus: 1. Overview of dementia: Definition, types, pathophysiology, risk factors, diagnosis, staging, pharmacological management and promoting brain health.  2. Sociological understanding of dementia.  3. Comprehensive health and social assessment for dementia.  4. Manifestations of dementia: physical, behavioural and psychosocial perspectives.  5. Communication with dementia clients.  6. Managing challenging behaviours.  7. Non-pharmacological interventions for dementia: Cognitive interventions for people with dementia; Practice sharing by music therapist and horticulture therapist.  8. Evidence-based research in dementia: Quantitative and qualitative approach.  9. Use of assistive technology in dementia care.  10. Interprofessional team approach in the care of older people with dementia and their caregivers and families: Community and social care services.  11. Advanced care planning for clients with dementia.  12. Tour visit to community care services for dementia.

title: Ethical and Financial Issues in Ageing
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to enhance students' understanding of the ethical issues relating to aged care. It focuses on the basic ethical principles and theories relating to gerontological practice; the ethical issues and dilemmas encountered in practice; the financial planning for older people; and the funding models for aged care services.

title: Aged Care Service Planning and Delivery Models
components:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the principles, concepts and skills involved in planning and delivering aged care services in a variety of geriatric settings, including community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. The basic concepts covered with regard to these settings include ageing in place, social involvement and participation, integrated community-based care, home-based care delivery model, discharge planning, interdisciplinary and cross-sectoral service coordination, and the residential care home accreditation system. The course highlights the notion of health and social care partnership, and a multi-dimensional perspective is adopted to facilitate students to examine the service planning and delivery model for the provision of community, rehabilitative and residential care services to older people.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Demonstrate an understanding of the principles, philosophies, and concepts of community, rehabilitative, and residential aged care and their relevance to older persons in a society locally and globally.  2. Understand the roles and functions of different health care and social welfare organisations in the provision of different levels of aged care services.  3. Differentiate the types of aged care services according to older persons’ level of care needs in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.  4. Demonstrate an understanding of the concepts, significance, and methods of optimising multi-sectoral collaboration between health care, social welfare and business organisations in the delivery of community, rehabilitative and residential care.  5. Describe innovative care models for delivering community, rehabilitative, and residential care services to older persons.  6. Discuss the knowledge and skills in coordinating multi-disciplinary and inter-sectoral aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.  7. Describe innovative strategies to monitor quality and promote excellence in the provision of aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
syllabus: Major concepts and topics to be covered:  1 Health care and social welfare organisations  1.1 Types, roles and functions of community care services  1.2 Types, roles and functions of rehabilitative care services in community  1.3 Types, roles and functions of rehabilitative care services in hospital  1.4 Types, roles and functions of residential care services   2 Models of delivering aged care services  2.1 Innovative service models in community care setting  2.2 Community self-help model  2.3 Social involvement and participation  2.4 Innovative care models for delivering rehabilitative care services in community  2.5 Innovative care models for delivering rehabilitative care services for discharge planning  2.6 Innovative service models in residential care setting   3 Service planning and delivery  3.1 The principles, philosophies, and concepts of community, rehabilitative, and residential aged care: local and global scenarios  3.2 Design thinking to promote social innovation in respond to ageing population  3.3 Elder abuse: The suffering in silence  3.4 Safety planning in elder abuse-role of gerontological professionals  3.5 Integrative and innovative practices for delivering residential care services  3.6 Adjustment of older people to residential care placements   4 Multi-sectoral collaboration in aged care provisions  4.1 The concepts and strategies of coordinating multi-disciplinary and inter-sectoral aged care  4.2 Landscape of social enterprises and social entrepreneurship in respond to ageing population  4.3 Rehabilitative service delivery: physiotherapy perspectives  4.4 Rehabilitative service delivery: occupational therapy perspectives  4.5 Multi-sectoral collaboration in managing and preventing elder abuse   5 Monitoring quality and excellence in aged care services  5.1 Principles and strategies to monitor quality and promote excellence in aged care services  5.2 Quality of care and accreditation system for residential care services
